contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.comment: rm line break
revision.text:
{{for|a full listing of computer's color palettes|List of palettes}} {{Refimprove|date=February 2008}} This '''list of monochrome and RGB palettes''' includes generic repertoires of colors ([[palette (computing)|color palette]]s) to produce [[black-and-white]] and [[RGB]] color pictures by a computer's display [[Computer hardware|hardware]], not necessarily the total number of such colors that can be simultaneously displayed in a given text or graphic mode of any machine. RGB is the most common method to produce colors for displays; so these complete RGB color repertoires have every possible combination of R-G-B triplets within any given maximum number of levels per component. For specific hardware and different methods to produce colors other than RGB, see the [[List of 8-bit computer hardware palettes]], the [[List of 16-bit computer hardware palettes]] and the [[List of videogame consoles palettes]]. For various software arrangements and sorts of colors, including other possible full RGB arrangements within 8-bit [[color depth]] displays, see the [[List of software palettes]]. Each palette is represented by a series of color patches. When the number of colors is low, a 1-pixel-size version of the palette appears below it, for easily comparing relative palette sizes. Huge palettes are given directly in one-color-per-pixel color patches. For each unique palette, an image color test chart and sample image ([[True Color|truecolor]] original follows) rendered with that palette (without [[Floyd‚ÄìSteinberg dithering|dithering]]) are given. The test chart shows the full 256 levels of the red, green, and blue (RGB) primary colors and cyan, magenta, and yellow complementary colors, along with a full 256-level grayscale. Gradients of RGB intermediate colors (orange, lime green, sea green, sky blue, violet, and fuchsia), and a full [[hue]] spectrum are also present. Color charts are not [[Gamma correction|gamma]] corrected. :{| style="border-style: none" border="0" cellpadding="0" |- || [[Image:RGB 24bits palette sample image.jpg]] || [[Image:RGB 24bits palette color test chart.png]] |} These elements illustrate the color depth and distribution of the colors of any given palette, and the sample image indicates how the color selection of such palettes could represent real-life images. These images are not necessarily representative of how the image would be displayed on the original graphics hardware, as the hardware may have additional limitations regarding the maximum display [[Display resolution|resolution]], [[pixel aspect ratio]] and color placement. For simulated sample images for notable computers, see the [[List of 8-bit computer hardware palettes]] and [[List of 16-bit computer hardware palettes]] articles. ==Monochrome palettes== These palettes only have some shades of gray, from black to white, both considered the most possible darker and lighter "grays", respectively. The general rule is that those palettes have 2n different shades of gray, where ''n'' is the number of bits needed to represent a single [[pixel]]. ===Monochrome (1-bit)=== [[Monochrome]] graphics displays typically have a black background with a white or light gray image, though green and amber [[monochrome monitor]]s were also common. Such a palette requires only one bit per pixel. :{| | [[Image:Bilevel 1bit palette sample image.png]] | [[Image:Bilevel 1bit palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:1-bit grayscale.gif|200px]] |} Where photo-realism was desired, these early computer systems had a heavy reliance on [[dithering]] to make up for the limits of the technology. :{| | [[File:Bilevel 1bit palette sample image - gimp dithered.png]] | [[File:RGB 24bits palette color test chart - 1-bit dithered.png]] |} :[[Image:Bilevel 1bit palette.png]] In some systems, as [[Hercules Graphics Card|Hercules]] and [[Color Graphics Adapter|CGA]] graphic cards for the [[IBM PC]], a bit value of 1 represents white pixels (light on) and a value of 0 the black ones (light off); others, like the [[Atari ST]] and [[Apple Macintosh]] with monochrome monitors, a bit value of 0 means a white pixel (no ink) and a value of 1 means a black pixel (dot of ink), which it approximates to the printing logic. ===2-bit Grayscale=== In a 2-bit color palette each pixel's value is represented by 2 bits resulting in a 4-value palette (22 = 4). :{| | [[Image:Grayscale 2bit palette sample image.png]] | [[Image:Grayscale 2bit palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:2-bit grayscale.gif|200px]] |} 2-bit dithering: :{| style="border-style: none" border="0" cellpadding="0" |- || [[File:Grayscale 2bit palette sample image - gimp dithered.png]] || [[File:RGB 24bits palette color test chart - 2-bit dithered.png]] |} It has black, white and two intermediate levels of gray as follows: :[[Image:Grayscale 2bit palette.png]] A monochrome 2-bit palette is used on: *The [[IBM Monochrome Display Adapter|Monochrome Display Adapter]] for the [[IBM Personal Computer|IBM PC]] *[[NeXT Computer]], [[NeXTcube]] and [[NeXTstation]] monochrome graphic displays. *Original [[Game Boy]] system portable [[videogame console]]. *[[PowerBook 150|Macintosh PowerBook 150]] monochrome LC displays. *[[Commodore Amiga]] with A2024 monochrome monitor in high-resolution mode.{{cite web|url=http://www.amiga-hardware.com/showhardware.cgi?HARDID=863 |title=Commodore: A2024 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302193812/https://www.amiga-hardware.com/showhardware.cgi?HARDID=863 |archivedate=2012-03-02 |df= }} *The original [[Amazon Kindle]] *The original [[Wonderswan]] {{clear}} ===4-bit Grayscale=== In a 4-bit color palette each pixel's value is represented by 4 bits resulting in a 16-value palette (24 = 16): :{| | [[Image:Grayscale 4bit palette sample image.png]] | [[Image:Grayscale 4bit palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:4-bit grayscale.gif|200px]] |} 4-bit grayscale dithering does a fairly good job of reducing visible banding of the level changes: :{| | [[File:Grayscale 4bit palette sample image - gimp dithered.png]] | [[File:RGB 24bits palette color test chart - 4-bit gray dithered.png]] |} :[[Image:Grayscale 4bit palette.png]] A monochrome 4-bit palette is used on: * [[MOS Technology VDC]] (on the [[Commodore 128]] with monochrome monitor) * [[Amstrad CPC]] series with a GT64/GT65 Green Monitor (16 unique green shades) * [[Amstrad CPC]] Plus series with the MM12 Monochrome monitor (16 shades of grey) * Some Apple [[PowerBook]]s equipped with monochrome displays like the [[PowerBook 5300]] ===8-bit Grayscale=== :{| | [[Image:Grayscale 8bits palette sample image.png]] | [[Image:Grayscale 8bits palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:8-bit grayscale.gif|200px]] |} In an 8-bit color palette each pixel's value is represented by 8 bits resulting in a 256-value palette (28 = 256). This is usually the maximum number of grays in ordinary monochrome systems; each image pixel occupies a single memory [[byte]]. :[[Image:Grayscale 8bits palette.png]] Most [[Image scanner|scanner]]s can capture images in 8-bit grayscale, and [[image file format]]s like [[TIFF]] and [[JPEG]] natively support this monochrome palette size. [[Alpha channel]]s employed for [[video overlay]] also use (conceptually) this palette. The gray level indicates the opacity of the blended image pixel over the background image pixel. ==Dichrome palettes== ===16-bit RG palette=== {{main|RG color space}} :{| | [[File:RG 16bits palette sample image.png]] | [[File:RG 16bits palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:Redgreen.png|200px]] |- | Additive RG | Additive RG color palette |} ===16-bit RB palette=== :{| | [[File:RB 16bits palette sample image.png]] | [[File:RB 16bits palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:Redblue.png|200px]] |- | Additive RB | Additive RB color palette |} ===16-bit GB palette=== :{| | [[File:GB 16bits palette sample image.png]] | [[File:GB 16bits palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:Greenblue.png|200px]] |- | Additive GB | Additive GB color palette |} ==Regular RGB palettes== Here are grouped those full RGB hardware palettes that have the same number of binary levels (i.e., the same number of [[bit]]s) for every red, green and blue components using the full [[RGB]] color model. Thus, the total number of colors are always the number of possible levels by component, ''n'', raised to a power of 3: ''n''√ó''n''√ó''n'' = ''n''3. ===3-bit RGB=== :{| | [[Image:RGB 3bits palette sample image.png]] | [[Image:RGB 3bits palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:3-bit RGB Cube.gif|200px]] |} 3-bit RGB dithering: :{| | [[File:RGB 24bits palette sample image - 3-bit RGB.png]] | [[File:RGB 24bits palette color test chart - 3-bit RGB dithered.png]] |} Systems with a 3-bit RGB palette use 1 bit for each of the red, green and blue color components. That is, each component is either "on" or "off" with no intermediate states. This results in an 8-color palette ((21)3 = 23 = 8) that have black, white, the three RGB primary colors red, blue and green and their correspondent complementary colors cyan, magenta and yellow as follows: :[[Image:RGB 3bits palette.png]] The color indices vary between implementations; therefore, index numbers are not given. The 3-bit RGB palette is used by: *The ECMA-48 standard for [[text terminal]]s (sometimes known as the "ANSI standard", although [[ANSI X3.64]] does not define colors) *[[Teletext]] Level 1/1.5 Teletext. *[[Videotex]] *[[TRS-80 Color Computer]] (in graphics mode, only 4 colors can be displayed simultaneously from fixed 4-colors palettes) *[[Oric]] *[[BBC Micro]] *The original NEC [[PC8801]] up to the MkII *The original NEC [[PC9801]] with original 8086 CPU before the VM/VX models *All [[Sharp X1]] models before the X1 Turbo Z *The [[Sharp MZ]] 700 *Fujitsu [[FM-7]], FM New 7, FM 77 before the FM77AV *[[Sinclair QL]] *The Macintosh SE with a color printer or external monitor *The [[SECAM]] version of the [[Atari 2600]] *The Color [[Maximite]], a PIC32 based microcomputer {{clear}} ===6-bit RGB=== :{| | [[Image:RGB 6bits palette sample image.png]] | [[Image:RGB 6bits palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:6-bit RGB Cube.gif|200px]] |} Systems with a 6-bit RGB palette use 2 bits for each of the red, green, and blue color components. This results in a (22)3 = 43 = 64-color palette as follows: :[[Image:RGB 6bits palette.png]] 6-bit RGB systems include the following: *[[Enhanced Graphics Adapter]] (EGA) for [[IBM Personal Computer/AT|IBM PC/AT]] (only 16 colors can be displayed simultaneously) *[[Sega Master System]] [[videogame console]] *[[GIME]] for [[TRS-80 Color Computer]] 3 (only 16 colors can be displayed simultaneously) *[[Pebble (watch)|Pebble Time]] smartwatch which has a 6-bit (64 color) e-paper display {{clear}} ===9-bit RGB=== :{| | [[Image:RGB 9bits palette sample image.png]] | [[Image:RGB 9bits palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:9-bit RGB Cube.gif|200px]] |} Systems with a 9-bit RGB palette use 3 bits for each of the red, green, and blue color components. This results in a (23)3 = 83 = 512-color palette as follows: :[[Image:RGB 9bits palette.png]] 9-bit RGB systems include the following: *[[Atari ST]] (Normally 4 to 16 at once without tricks) *[[MSX2]] computers (up to 256 at once) *[[Sega Genesis]] [[videogame console]] (64 at once) *[[Sega Nomad]] *[[TurboGrafx-16]] (NEC PC-Engine) *The NEC [[PC8801]] Mk II SR and later models (8 of them at once) *The [[Mindset computer]] {{clear}} ===12-bit RGB=== :{| | [[Image:RGB 12bits palette sample image.png]] | [[Image:RGB 12bits palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:12-bit RGB Cube.gif|200px]] |} Systems with a 12-bit RGB palette use 4 bits for each of the red, green, and blue color components. This results in a (24)3 = 163 = 4096-color palette. 12-bit color can be represented with three hexadecimal digits, also known as [[Web_colors#Shorthand_hexadecimal_form|shorthand hexadecimal form]], which is commonly used in web design. The palette is as follows: :[[Image:RGB 12bits palette.png]] 12-bit RGB systems include the following: *[[Original Chip Set|Amiga OCS]]/[[Enhanced Chip Set|ECS]] (32, 64, or 4,096 colors) *[[Apple IIgs]] Video Graphics Chip (3,200 colors) *[[Atari ST#STE|Atari ST]]e (16 colors) *[[Acorn Archimedes]] *[[Game Gear|Sega Game Gear]] (32 colors) *[[Teletext#Level_2.5_teletext_.2F_Hi-Text|Hi-Text]] Level 2.5+ Teletext *[[Neo Geo Pocket Color]] (147 colors) *[[Atari Lynx]] (16 colors) *NEC [[PC-9801]] VM/VX models typically equipped with a NEC V30 or better, but before the PC9821 Series. *The [[Sharp X1]] Turbo Z Series *Fujitsu [[FM-7]]7AV *The [[Amstrad CPC]] 664Plus, 6128Plus and GX4000 (32 colors) *[[NeXTstation|NeXTstation Color and NeXTstation Turbo Color]] *[[WonderSwan|WonderSwan Color]] The [[Allegro_(software)|Allegro library]] supported in the (legacy) version 4, an emulated 12-bit color mode example code ("ex12bit.c"), using 8-bit indexed color in VGA/SVGA. It used two pixels for each emulated pixel, paired horizontally, and a specifically adapted 256-color palette. One range of the palette was many brightnesses of one primary color (say green), and another range of the other two primaries mixed together at different amounts and brightnesses (red and blue). It effectively reduced the horizontal resolution by half, but allowed a 12-bit "true color" in DOS and other 8-bit VGA/SVGA modes. The effect also somewhat reduced the total brightness of the screen.{{cite web|url=https://www.systutorials.com/docs/linux/man/3-ex12bit/|title=ex12bit - How to fake a 12-bit truecolor mode on an 8-bit card. Allegro game programming library. - Linux Man Pages (3)|website=www.systutorials.com}} [[File:Allegro_4_-_ex12bit.c.png|500px]] {{clear}} ===15-bit RGB=== :{| | [[Image:RGB 15bits palette sample image.png]] | [[Image:RGB 15bits palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:15-bit RGB Cube.gif|200px]] |} Systems with a 15-bit RGB palette use 5 bits for each of the red, green, and blue color components. This results in a (25)3 = 323 = 32,768-color palette (commonly known as [[Highcolor]]) as follows: :[[Image:RGB 15bits palette.png]] 15-bit systems include: *[[Super Nintendo Entertainment System]] (256 colors) *[[Truevision]] [[TARGA]] and [[AT-Vista]] graphic cards for [[IBM PC-AT]] and compatibles, and [[NU-Vista]] for [[Apple Macintosh]] *Later models of [[Super VGA]] (SVGA) [[IBM PC compatible]] graphic cards *[[Nintendo]] [[Game Boy Color]]/[[Game Boy Advance|Advance]]/[[Game Boy Advance SP|SP]]/[[Game Boy Micro|Micro]] pocket videoconsoles *[[Nintendo DS]] (2D output) *[[Neo Geo AES]]/[[Neo Geo CD]] videogame consoles (4096 colors) * The [[Sega 32X]] Addon for the Mega Drive/Genesis {{clear}} ===18-bit RGB=== :{| | [[Image:RGB 18bits palette sample image.png]] | [[Image:RGB 18bits palette color test chart.png]] | [[File:18-bit RGB Cube.gif|200px]] |} Systems with an 18-bit RGB palette use 6 bits for each of the red, green, and blue color components. This results in a (26)3 = 643 = 262,144-color palette as follows: :[[Image:RGB 18bits palette.png]] 18-bit RGB systems include the following: *[[Video Graphics Array]] (VGA) for [[IBM Personal System/2|IBM PS/2]] and [[IBM PC compatible]]s (256 simultaneous colors from a palette of 262,144) *[[Atari Falcon]] (256 colors) *[[Nintendo DS]] (3D output and 2D ''blended'' output) *Used internally by many LCD monitors {{clear}} ===24-bit RGB=== :{| | [[Image:RGB 24bits palette sample image.jpg]] | [[Image:RGB 24bits palette color test chart.png]] |} Often known as [[True Color|truecolor]] and '''millions of colors''', 24-bit color is the highest color depth normally used, and is available on most modern display systems and software. Its color palette contains (28)3 = 2563 = 16,777,216 colors. 24-bit color can be represented with six hexadecimal digits. This is approximately the number of individual colors the human eye can distinguish within the limited gamut of a typical display{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}. [[File:16777216colors.png|thumb|left|200px|All 16,777,216 colors (downscaled, click image for full resolution).]] {{clear}} The complete palette (shown above) needs a squared image of 4,096 pixels wide (50.33 MB uncompressed), and there is not enough room in this page to show it at full. This can be imagined as 256 stacked squares like the following, every one of them having the same given value for the red component, from 0 to 255. The color transitions in these patches must be seen as continuous. If you see ''color stepping'' ([[Colour banding|banding]]) inside, then probably your display is using a [[Highcolor]] (15- or 16- bits RGB, 32,768 or 65,536 colors) mode or lesser. :{| | [[Image:RGB 24bits palette R0.png]]
Red = 0 | [[Image:RGB 24bits palette R85.png]]
Red = 85 (1/3 of 255) |- | [[Image:RGB 24bits palette R170.png]]
Red = 170 (2/3 of 255) | [[Image:RGB 24bits palette R255.png]]
Red = 255 |} [[File:16777216colors_diffpatt.png|thumb|left|200px|All 16,777,216 colors in the same pattern as the other RGB palettes above (downscaled, click image for full resolution).]] {{clear}} This is also the number of colors used in true color image files, like [[Truevision TGA]], [[TIFF]], [[JPEG]] (the last internally encoded as [[YCbCr]]) and [[Windows Bitmap]], captured with [[Image scanner|scanner]]s and [[digital camera]]s, as well as those created with [[3D computer graphic]]s software. 24-bit RGB systems include: * Amiga [[Advanced Graphics Architecture]] (256 or 262144 colors) * [[Nintendo 3DS]] * [[PlayStation Vita]] * Later models of [[Super VGA]] (SVGA) [[IBM PC compatible]] graphic cards * [[Truevision]] [[AT-Vista]] graphic cards for [[IBM PC-AT]] and compatibles, and [[NU-Vista]] for [[Apple Macintosh]]. * The [[Philips CD-i]] * [[Nintendo Switch]] {{clear}} === 30-bit RGB === {| | style="color: black; background-color: #C0C0C0" | (No simulation available) |} Some newer graphics cards support [[Color depth#Beyond truecolor|30-bit RGB and higher]]. Its color palette contains (210)3 = 10243 = 1,073,741,824 colors. However, there are few operating systems or applications that support this mode yet. For some people, it may be hard to distinguish between higher color palettes than 24-bit color offers. However, the range of [[luminance]], or gray scale, offered in a 30-bit color system would have 1,024 levels of luminance rather than the 256 of the common standard 24-bit, to which the human eye is more sensitive than to hue. This reduces the [[Colour_banding|banding effect]] for gradients across large areas.{{cite web|url=https://www.rtings.com/tv/tests/picture-quality/gradient|title=Gradients on TVs: Color bit depth|publisher=}} ==Non-regular RGB palettes== These also are full RGB palette repertories, but either they do not have the same number of levels for every red, green and blue components, or they are bit levels based. Nevertheless, all of them are used in very popular [[personal computer]]s. For further details on color palettes for these systems, see the article [[List of 8-bit computer hardware palettes]]. ===4-bit RGBI=== :{| style="border-style: none" border="0" cellpadding="0" |- || [[Image:RGBI 4bits palette sample image.png]] || [[Image:RGBI 4bits palette color test chart.png]] |} The 4-bit RGBI palette is similar to the 3-bit RGB palette but adds one bit for ''intensity''. This results in each of the colors of the 3-bit palette to have a ''dark'' and ''bright'' variant giving a total of 23√ó2 = 16 colors. This 4-bits RGBI schema is used in several platforms with variations, so the table given below is a simple reference for the palette richness, and not an actual implemented palette. For this reason, no numbers are assigned to each color, and color order is arbitrary. :[[Image:RGBI 4bits palette.png]] Note that "dark white" is a lighter gray than "bright black". The 4-bits RGBI palettes are used by: *[[Color Graphics Adapter]], with brown instead of dark yellow). On CGA, setting a color "bright" added ‚Öì of the maximum to ''all three'' channels' brightness, so the "bright" colors were whiter shades of their 3-bit counterparts. Each of the other bits increased a channel by ‚Öî, except that dark yellow had only ‚Öì green and was therefore brown instead of ochre. ** The CGA palette was the default for [[Enhanced Graphics Adapter|EGA]], [[Video Graphics Array|VGA]] and [[Microsoft Windows]] 3.x (on the [[IBM PC]] and compatibles), although other palettes were available. *[[MOS Technology VDC]] (on the [[Commodore 128]]) *[[ZX Spectrum]] (with two black, black with bright is the same as black without bright) *[[Sharp MZ]] 800 {{clear}} ===3-level RGB === :{| style="border-style: none" border="0" cellpadding="0" |- || [[Image:AmstradCPC palette sample image.png]] || [[Image:AmstradCPC palette color test chart.png]] |} The 3-level (''''not'''' '''bits''') RGB uses three level for every red, green and blue color components, resulting in a 33 = 27 colors palette as follows: :[[Image:AmstradCPC palette.png]] This palette is used by: * The [[Amstrad CPC 464]] series of personal computers excluding the Plus models (up to 16 colors simultaneously) * The [[Toshiba Pasopia 7]] {{clear}} ===3-3-2 bit RGB=== :{| style="border-style: none" border="0" cellpadding="0" |- || [[Image:MSX2 Screen8 palette sample image.png]] || [[Image:MSX2 Screen8 palette color test chart.png]] |} The 3-3-2 bit RGB use 3 bits for each of the red and green color components, and 2 bits for the blue component, due to the lesser sensitivity of the common human eye to this primary color. This results in an 8√ó8√ó4 = 256-color palette as follows: :[[Image:MSX2 Screen8 palette.png]] This palette is used by *The [[MSX#MSX2|MSX2]] series of personal computers. *Palette 4 of the [[Professional Graphics Controller|IBM PGC]] (palette 2 gives 2-3-3 bit RGB and palette 3 gives 3-2-3 bit RGB). *VGA built-in output of the [[Digilent Inc.]] NEXYS 2, NEXYS 3 and BASYS2 FPGA boards. *The [[Uzebox]] gaming console * [[SGI Indy]] 8-bit XL graphics *The [[Tiki 100]] personal computer (only 16 colors can be displayed simultaneously) {{clear}} ===16-bit RGB=== :{| style="border-style: none" border="0" cellpadding="0" |- || [[Image:RGB 16bits palette sample image.png]] || [[Image:RGB 16bits palette color test chart.png]] |} Most modern systems support 16-bit color. It is sometimes referred to as [[Highcolor]] (along with the 15-bit RGB), '''medium color''' or '''thousands of colors'''. It utilizes a color palette of 32√ó64√ó32 = 65,536 colors. Usually, there are 5 bits allocated for the red and blue color components (32 levels each) and 6 bits for the green component (64 levels), due to the greater sensitivity of the common human eye to this color. This doubles the 15-bit RGB palette. The 16-bit RGB palette using 6 bits for the green component: :[[Image:RGB 16bits palette.png]] The [[Atari Falcon]] and the [[XGA|Extended Graphics Array]] (XGA) for [[IBM Personal System/2|IBM PS/2]] use the 16-bit RGB palette. It must be noticed that not all systems using 16-bit color depth employ the 16-bit, 32-64-32 level RGB palette. Platforms like the Sharp [[X68000]] home computer or the [[Neo Geo (system)|Neo Geo]] video game console employs the 15-bit RGB palette (5 bits are used for red, green, and blue), but the last bit specifies a less significant intensity or luminance. The 16-bit mode of the [[Truevision]] [[Truevision TGA|TARGA]]/[[AT-Vista]]/[[NU-Vista]] graphic cards and its associated TGA file format also uses 15-bit RGB, but it devotes its remaining bit as a simple [[alpha channel]] for [[video overlay]]. The [[Atari Falcon]] can also be switched into a matching mode by setting of an "overlay" bit in the graphics processor mode register when in 16-bit mode, meaning it can actually display in ''either'' 15- or 16-bit color depth depending on application. {{clear}} ==See also== *[[Bitmap]] *[[CLUT|Color Lookup Table]] *[[Computer display]] *[[Grayscale]] *[[Indexed color]] *[[List of home computers by video hardware]] *[[Palette (computing)]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Monochrome and RGB palettes}} [[Category:Computer graphics]] [[Category:Color depths]] [[Category:Computing output devices]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Magatama.png|right|thumb|Magatama, dating from J≈çmon period to 8th century]] {{Nihongo|'''Magatama'''|ÂãæÁéâ|extra=less frequently {{lang|ja|Êõ≤Áéâ}}}} are curved, [[comma]]-shaped [[bead]]s that appeared in prehistoric [[Japan]] from the [[J≈çmon period|Final J≈çmon period]] through the [[Kofun period]], approximately ca. 1000 BCE to the sixth century CE.<ref name="kokushi">{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Kokushi Daijiten (ÂõΩÂè≤Â§ßËæûÂÖ∏) | title = Magatama | url = http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ | accessdate = 2012-04-02 | year = 2012 | publisher = Shogakukan | location = Tokyo|language=ja}}</ref> The beads, also described as "jewels", were made of primitive stone and earthen materials in the early period, but by the end of the Kofun period were made almost exclusively of [[jade]]. Magatama originally served as decorative jewelry, but by the end of the Kofun period functioned as ceremonial and religious objects.<ref name="kawade">{{Citation | editor = Â∑ùÂá∫Â≠ùÈõÑ (Kawade Hikio) | year = 1959 | title = Nihon rekishi daijiten (Êó•Êú¨Ê≠¥Âè≤Â§ßËæûÂÖ∏) | volume = 17 | publisher = Kawade Sh≈çb≈ç Shinsha (Ê≤≥Âá∫Êõ∏ÊàøÊñ∞Á§æ) | place = T≈çky≈ç (Êù±‰∫¨) | language = Japanese | page = 54 | oclc = 20762728}}</ref> Archaeological evidence suggests that magatama were produced in specific areas of Japan and were widely dispersed throughout the [[Japanese archipelago]] via trade routes.<ref name="barnes">{{Citation | last = Barnes | first = Gina Lee | year = 1999 | title = The rise of civilization in East Asia: the archaeology of China, Korea and Japan | edition = 1st paperback | publisher = Thames and Hudson | place = New York, N.Y. | isbn = 9780500279748 | oclc = 43664418}}</ref>
==J≈çmon period==
Magatama first appeared in Japan in the [[J≈çmon period|Final J≈çmon period]], c. 1000 to 300 BCE, and in this period magatama were made from relatively simple, naturally occurring materials, including [[clay]], [[talc]], [[slate]], [[quartz]], [[gneiss]], [[jadeite]], [[nephrite]], and [[serpentinite]].<ref name="nipponika">{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Nihon Daihyakka Zensho (Nipponika) (Êó•Êú¨Â§ßÁôæÁßëÂÖ®Êõ∏ („Éã„ÉÉ„Éù„Éã„Ç´)) | title = Magatama | url = http://rekishi.jkn21.com/| accessdate = 2012-03-26 | year = 2012 | publisher = Shogakukan | location = Tokyo|language=ja}}</ref> They lack the uniformity of design found in magatama produced in later periods.<ref name="kawade"/> Magatama from the J≈çmon period were irregularly shaped, lacked continuity in form from region to region, and have been called "[[Stone Age]] magatama" for this reason.<ref name="kokushi"/><ref name="nipponika"/> Magatama are thought to be an imitation of the teeth of large animals, pierced with a hole, which are found in earlier J≈çmon remains.<ref name="dijitaru-magatama">{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Dijitaru daijisen| title = Magatama | url = http://rekishi.jkn21.com/| accessdate = 2012-04-01 | year = 2012 | publisher = Shogakukan | location = Tokyo|language=ja}}</ref> These resemble magatama, but more recent scholarship indicates that these early J≈çmon may have simply had a decorative function, and have no relationship to magatama.<ref name="nipponika"/> Magatama in the J≈çmon period appear to have moved from the purely decorative to having a status and ceremonial function by the end of the period.<ref>{{Citation | last = Naumann | first = Nelly |authorlink=Nelly Naumann | year = 2000 | title = Japanese prehistory : the material and spiritual culture of the J≈çmon period | chapter = From early to middle J≈çmon | series = Asien- und Afrika-Studien der Humboldt-Universit√§t zu Berlin | volume = 6 | publisher = Harrassowitz | place = Wiesbaden | page = 18 | isbn = 9783447043298 | oclc = 45797690}}</ref> A "middle J≈çmon exchange network" may have existed, whereby magatama were produced in regions where materials for their manufacture were readily plentiful. Jade and talc examples produced in bead-making villages located in present-day [[Itoigawa, Niigata]] have been found at a large number of sites in along the northern coast, central mountains, and [[Kant≈ç region]].<ref>{{Citation | last = Barnes | first = Gina Lee | year = 1999 | title = The rise of civilization in East Asia: the archaeology of China, Korea and Japan | edition = 1st paperback | publisher = Thames and Hudson | place = New York, N.Y. | page = 30 | isbn = 9780500279748 | oclc = 43664418}}</ref>
===Archaeological sites (J≈çmon)===
*Examples of magatama from the J≈çmon period have been discovered in large numbers at the Kamegaoka site in [[Tsugaru, Aomori|Tsugaru]], [[Aomori Prefecture]]. The Kamegaoka remains are among the largest known J≈çmon settlement in Japan, and the magatama, among other decorative objects found, may be an indicator of the high social status of the settlement.<ref>{{cite book | last = Aikens | first = C. Melvin | last2 = Higuchi | first2 =Takayasu | title = Prehistory of Japan | place = New York | publisher = Academic Press | series = Studies in archaeology | chapter = The Jomon period | pages = 165 | year = 1982 | isbn = 9780120452804 | oclc = 7738449}}</ref> *Other sites associated with the Kamegaoka settlement have yielded magatama, including the ≈åboriya [[midden|shell mound]], in the northwest corner of [[≈åfunato Bay]], which yielded a huge number of beads, as well as the Karekawa site, near [[Hachinohe, Aomori|Hachinohe]], [[Aomori Prefecture]]. Remains from the Karekawa site can be seen at the [[Karekawa Achaeogical Museum]] in Hachinohe.<ref>{{Citation | last = Naumann | first = Nelly | year = 2000 | title = Japanese prehistory : the material and spiritual culture of the J≈çmon period | chapter = Final J≈çmon in northeast Japan--the Kamegaoka culture | series = Asien- und Afrika-Studien der Humboldt-Universit√§t zu Berlin | volume = 6 | publisher = Harrassowitz | place = Wiesbaden | page = 46 | isbn = 9783447043298 | oclc = 45797690}}</ref> *Stone and clay magatama and magatama-like [[bead]]s have also been discovered at the Amataki site, [[Ninohe, Iwate|Ninohe]], [[Iwate Prefecture]], Osagata site, [[Ibaraki Prefecture]], and the Kou site, [[Fujiidera, Osaka|Fujiidera]], [[Osaka Prefecture]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Aikens | first = C. Melvin | last2 = Higuchi | first2 =Takayasu | title = Prehistory of Japan | place = New York | publisher = Academic Press | series = Studies in archaeology | chapter = The Jomon period | pages = 173 | year = 1982 | isbn = 9780120452804 | oclc = 7738449}}</ref> *Numerous magatama at the ≈åishi site, [[Bungo-≈çno]], [[≈åita Prefecture]], [[Kyushu]] show signs of being used for ceremonial, rather than decorative, purposes.<ref>{{cite book | last = Aikens | first = C. Melvin | last2 = Higuchi | first2 =Takayasu | title = Prehistory of Japan | place = New York | publisher = Academic Press | series = Studies in archaeology | chapter = The Jomon period | pages = 181 | year = 1982 | isbn = 9780120452804 | oclc = 7738449}}</ref> *The [[Sannai-Maruyama site]], excavated 1992 in [[Aomori, Aomori|Aomori]], [[Aomori Prefecture]], yielded 3 large jade beads, 5.5 cm √ó 6.5 cm.<ref>{{Citation | last = Naumann | first = Nelly | year = 2000 | title = Japanese prehistory : the material and spiritual culture of the J≈çmon period | chapter = From early to middle J≈çmon | series = Asien- und Afrika-Studien der Humboldt-Universit√§t zu Berlin | volume = 6 | publisher = Harrassowitz | place = Wiesbaden | page = 15 | isbn = 9783447043298 | oclc = 45797690}}</ref>
==Yayoi period== [[File:Magatama40.JPG|left|thumb|Agate magatama, {{Nihongo|[[Kobe Archaeology Center]]|Á•ûÊà∏Â∏ÇÂüãËîµÊñáÂåñË≤°„Çª„É≥„Çø„Éº|K≈çbeshi Maiz≈ç Bunkazai SentƒÅ}}]]
Magatama in the [[Yayoi period]], c. 300 BCE to 300 CE, are notably different from J≈çmon-period magatama. The jewels moved from a primitive, non-standard form towards more polished and uniform form in this period.<ref name="kawade"/> The technology to cut large gemstones and polish jewels notably advanced in the Yayoi period.<ref>{{Citation | last = Sait≈ç | first = Tadashi | year = 1958 | title = Genshi (ÂéüÂßã) | chapter = Seikatsu y≈çshiki no hatten (ÁîüÊ¥ªÊßòÂºè„ÅÆÁô∫Â±ï) | series = Nihon zenshi (Êó•Êú¨ÂÖ®Âè≤) | volume = 1 | publisher = T≈çky≈ç Daigaku Shuppankai | place = T≈çky≈ç | language = Japanese | page = 82 | oclc = 35922174}}</ref> Refined materials such as jadeite, serpentinite, and [[glass]] replaced the less sophisticated materials of the J≈çmon period.<ref name="nipponika"/> Yayoi period magatama are noted for their reverse C-shaped form, which by the end of the period became an almost squared shape.<ref name="nipponika"/> From the Yayoi period on magatama uniformly feature a bored hole that allowed the jewels to be held on a string.
The Yayoi period is marked by specific centers specializing in magatama and the widespread trade of magatama. The period is marked by the formation of power centers that came to be individual states. The development of weapons increased in this period to protect increasingly developed rice fields and fishing rights. Trade greatly increased in this period, as did the specialization of production of certain items, including magatama. Magatama producing areas exchanged their product with other products, specifically [[rice]], leading to the widespread distribution of magatama across Japan.<ref name="yomiuri-kuni">{{Citation | editor = Okada, Akio| year = 1959 | title = Nihon no hajimari (Êó•Êú¨„ÅÆ„ÅØ„Åò„Åæ„Çä) | chapter = Kuniguni no matomari (ÂõΩ„ÄÖ„ÅÆ„Åæ„Å®„Åæ„Çä) | series = Nihon no rekishi (Êó•Êú¨„ÅÆÊ≠¥Âè≤) | volume = 1 | publisher = Yomiuri Shinbunsha | place = T≈çky≈ç | language = Japanese | page = 110 | oclc = 33688869|display-editors=etal}}</ref> Magatama were commonly used to create necklaces and bracelets worn on the wrists or ankles. The necklace was typically constructed of jadeite magatama separated by cylindrical bored-holed pieces of jasper. Small beads of dark-blue glass are also not uncommon on the necklace. The bracelet was typically also used shells from the coastal areas of Shikoku and the Inland Sea, wood, and bronze.<ref>{{Citation | editor = Okada, Akio| year = 1959 | title = Nihon no hajimari (Êó•Êú¨„ÅÆ„ÅØ„Åò„Åæ„Çä) | chapter = Kawatte kita shakai seikatsu (Â§â„Çè„Å£„Å¶„Åç„ÅüÁ§æ‰ºöÁîüÊ¥ª) | series = Nihon no rekishi (Êó•Êú¨„ÅÆÊ≠¥Âè≤) | volume = 1 | publisher = Yomiuri Shinbunsha | place = T≈çky≈ç | language = Japanese | page = 99 | oclc = 33688869|display-editors=etal}}</ref> In this period the use of the [[mirror]], [[sword]], and jewels as status symbols for village, and later regional leaders of all kinds, emerged in the Yayoi period, and point to the origin of the mirror, sword, and magatama as the [[Imperial Regalia of Japan]].<ref name="yomiuri-1">{{Citation | editor = Okada, Akio| year = 1959 | title = Nihon no hajimari (Êó•Êú¨„ÅÆ„ÅØ„Åò„Åæ„Çä) | series = Nihon no rekishi (Êó•Êú¨„ÅÆÊ≠¥Âè≤) | volume = 1 | publisher = Yomiuri Shinbunsha | place = T≈çky≈ç | language = Japanese | page = 122 | oclc = 33688869|display-editors=etal}}</ref>
The ''[[Records of the Three Kingdoms]]'', the earliest historical document with a reference to Japan, describes the [[Wa (Japan)|Wa people]], an ancient country of [[Yamatai]], and its queen, [[Himiko]]. The ''Record'' indicates that when Himiko died her relative Iyo, a girl of thirteen, was made queen and sent a delegation of twenty officials under Yazuku, an imperial general, to offer tribute to the [[Northern Wei]] court. "The delegation visited the capital and [] offered to the court five thousand white gems and two pieces of carved jade, as well as twenty pieces of brocade with variegated designs."<ref>{{cite book | last = Tsunoda | first = Ryunosuke| title = Sources of Japanese tradition | publisher = Columbia University Press | location = New York | series = Records and civilization, sources and studies | chapter = The earliest records of Japan | pages = 8‚Äì16 | year = 1958 | isbn = 0231022549|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The carved jade in the ''Record'' likely describes a tribute of two jade magatama.
===Archaeological sites (Yayoi)=== [[File:Tamatsukuri-inari-jinja museum.jpeg|right|thumb|Museum housing artifacts of magatama production, Tamatsukuri Inari Shrine, Osaka]]
*The large-scale Yayoi period remains at the [[Yoshinogari site]], [[Yoshinogari, Saga|Yoshinogari]] and [[Kanzaki, Saga|Kanzaki]] in [[Saga Prefecture]] revealed examples of [[lead glass]] magatama typical of the Yayoi period.<ref>{{cite book | last = Kidder | first = J. Edward | title = Himiko and Japan's elusive chiefdom of Yamatai archaeology, history, and mythology | publisher = University of Hawai'i Press | location = Honolulu | pages = 91 | year = 2007 | isbn = 9780824830359}}</ref> *In 2003 the excavation of a large Yayoi period settlement in [[Tawaramoto, Nara]], revealed two large jade magatama, one {{Convert|4.64|cm|in}}, the second {{Convert|3.63|cm|in}} in length. The larger Tawaramoto magatama is the 10th largest found to date in Japan. Both jade magatama from the site are of unusually high-quality brilliant green jade.<ref>[http://www.47news.jp/CN/200309/CN2003091801000474.html Âº•Áîü„ÅßÊúÄÂ§ßÁ¥ö„ÅÆ„Å≤„Åô„ÅÑË£ΩÂìÅ„ÄÄÂîêÂè§„ÉªÈçµÈÅ∫Ë∑°Âá∫Âúü„ÅÆÂãæÁéâ]{{ja icon}}</ref> *One known center of Yayoi magatama production was in the area of the [[Tamatsukuri Inari Shrine]] in [[Osaka]]. Tamatsukuri literally means "jewel making" and a [[guild]], the Tamatsukuri-be, was active from the Yayoi period. An existing jewel at the shrine is said to have great spiritual power. Magatama appear on all sorts of implements of the present-day temple, including [[amulet]]s, roof [[tile]]s, and lanterns. The [[Inari ≈åkami|inari]] female [[fox]] at the gate of a subshrine of Tamatsukuri Inari Shrine wears a necklace of magatama. The shrine has an exhibit on the history and production of magatama.<ref>{{Citation | last = Smyers | first = Karen Ann | year = 1999 | title = The fox and the jewel: shared and private meanings in contemporary Japanese inari worship | chapter = Introducing Inari | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | place = Honolulu | pages = 23‚Äì24 | isbn = 9780824820589 | oclc = 39523475}}</ref>
==Kofun period== [[Image:Magatamarm.jpg|thumb|Necklace of jade magatama from a Japanese burial]] [[Image:Magatamas.JPG|thumb|Magatamas in Kofun period]]
Magatama became very common in the [[Kofun period]], c. CE 250 to CE 538, and by the end of the period almost all [[kofun]] [[tumulus|tumuli]] contained magatama.<ref name="kawade"/> In the early Kofun period magatama were made from jadeite as in earlier periods, but by the middle of the period were made from [[jasper]], and by the end of the period, almost exclusively of [[agate]] and [[jade]].<ref name="nipponika"/> Magatama capped by silver or gold also appear towards the end of the period. Large magatama made of [[talc]], imitations of smaller ones made of more precious materials, were used as [[grave goods]].<ref name="nipponika"/> Magatama are found in [[kofun]] tumuli across Japan from the period. Their use went from merely decorative to sacred and ceremonial grave goods.<ref name="nipponika"/><ref name="yomiuri">{{Citation | editor = Okada, Akio| year = 1959 | title = Nihon no hajimari (Êó•Êú¨„ÅÆ„ÅØ„Åò„Åæ„Çä) | series = Nihon no rekishi (Êó•Êú¨„ÅÆÊ≠¥Âè≤) | volume = 1 | publisher = Yomiuri Shinbunsha | place = T≈çky≈ç | language = Japanese | page = 29 | oclc = 33688869|display-editors=etal}}</ref> {{Nihongo|Ch≈çjigashira magatama|‰∏ÅÂ≠óÈ†≠ÂãæÁéâ}} are magatama with inscriptions that look like flowers of the [[clove]] tree and have a hole suitable to attach to a string.<ref name="kawade"/> These first appear in the Kofun period.<ref name="kokushi"/> In the Kofun period magatama appear on necklaces, with several magatama set between bored [[cylinder]]s. Archeological remains show evidence of similar ankle bracelets, but they are less common. Clay [[haniwa]] funerary objects of the Kofun period commonly depict people wearing the necklaces and ankle bracelets.<ref>{{Citation | last = Holtom | first = Daniel Clarence | year = 1928 | title = The Japanese enthronement ceremonies; with an account of the imperial regalia | chapter = The jewels | publisher = Kyo Bun Kwan | publication-place = Tokyo | page = 33 | oclc = 1983823}}</ref>
===Archaeological sites (Kofun)===
Examples of stone magatama from the Kofun period are especially numerous.
*An excavation of the Kamegaoka Kofun, [[Kishiwada, Osaka]], revealed a local who had been buried with a jade, jasper, and alabaster magatama necklace, as well as magatama placed near the feet. A bronze mirror imported from China accompanying the burial is dated to 239 CE.<ref>{{cite book | last = Aikens | first = C. Melvin | last2 = Higuchi | first2 =Takayasu | title = Prehistory of Japan | place = New York | publisher = Academic Press | series = Studies in archaeology | chapter = The Kofun period | pages = 264 | year = 1982 | isbn = 9780120452804 | oclc = 7738449}}</ref> The kofun is a Designated Historical Spot of the city of Kishiwada. *Ceremonial offerings from a burial from the Kisami-Araida area of [[Shimoda, Shizuoka]], reveal clay reproductions of magatama used as effigies. The excavation of the Ubusuna Kofun<ref name="kyotango">[http://www.city.kyotango.kyoto.jp/service/digitalmuseum/siteibunkazai/ubusunayamakofun.html Âè≤Ë∑°„ÄÄÁî£ÂúüÂ±±Âè§Â¢≥]{{ja icon}}</ref> in [[Ky≈çtango]], Kyoto yielded two fully intact magatama necklaces of jade and agate with segments between 1.7 and 5.1 cm in length.<ref name="kyotango"/><ref>{{cite book | last = Aikens | first = C. Melvin | last2 = Higuchi | first2 =Takayasu | title = Prehistory of Japan | place = New York | publisher = Academic Press | series = Studies in archaeology | chapter = The Kofun period | pages = 268 | year = 1982 | isbn = 9780120452804 | oclc = 7738449}}</ref> *The large Muro Miyayama Kofun of [[Katsuragi, Nara]], on the Yamato Plain, 238 mm in length, was plundered long before its excavation, but revealed 600 talc ceremonial magatama among other funerary objects, which also included 10 bronze Han Chinese mirrors.<ref>{{cite book | last = Aikens | first = C. Melvin | last2 = Higuchi | first2 =Takayasu | title = Prehistory of Japan | place = New York | publisher = Academic Press | series = Studies in archaeology | chapter = The Kofun period | pages = 275‚Äì276 | year = 1982 | isbn = 9780120452804 | oclc = 7738449}}</ref> *The [[Hiraide remains]] of [[Shiojiri, Nagano]], is one of the three largest prehistoric sites in Japan, and was far from any regional power center. The Hiraide site not only includes typical Kofun period remains, but also objects associated with modern Shinto ceremonial practice. Nevertheless, kofun in Hiraide reveal both plain and elaborate magatama among other funerary objects.<ref>{{cite book | last = Aikens | first = C. Melvin | last2 = Higuchi | first2 =Takayasu | title = Prehistory of Japan | place = New York | publisher = Academic Press | series = Studies in archaeology | chapter = Hiraide: village life during the Kofun period | pages = 303 | year = 1982 | isbn = 9780120452804 | oclc = 7738449}}</ref> *The Sakurai Kofun in [[Sakurai, Nara]], excavated in 1949, represents a kofun from the final phase of the Kofun period, and is possibly from a ruler associated with the imperial family. The kofun is {{Convert|25|m|ft}} high and shows evidence of being surrounded by a [[moat]]. Among the very large number of funerary objects were high-quality weapons, including swords, 10 mirrors, and a necklace of jadeite magatama, agate cylinders, and glass beads used to make a magatama-style necklace.<ref>{{Citation | last = Inoue | first = Mitsusada | year = 1965 | title = Shinwa kara rekishi he (Á•ûË©±„Åã„ÇâÊ≠¥Âè≤„Å∏) | chapter = Nazo no seiki („Å™„Åû„ÅÆ‰∏ñÁ¥Ä)„ÄÄ| edition = Shohan | series = Êó•Êú¨„ÅÆÊ≠¥Âè≤ (Nihon no rekishi) | volume = 1 | publisher = Ch≈´≈ç K≈çronsha | place = T≈çky≈ç | language = Japanese | pages = 309‚Äì310 | oclc = 21390677}}</ref>
== Origin of magatama forms ==
Archaeologists and historians are unable yet to explain what the origins of magatama forms are, or whether these forms can be traced back to one convergent source. However, these alternative explanations have been provided:<ref>Nishimura, Y. (2018). The Evolution of Curved Beads (Magatama ÂãæÁéâ/Êõ≤Áéâ) in J≈çmon Period Japan and the Development of Individual Ownership. Asian Perspectives 57(1), 105-158. University of Hawai'i Press. Retrieved October 18, 2018, from Project MUSE database.</ref>
* Magatama may be fashioned after animal fangs/teeth * Magatama may be modeled after the shape of fetuses * Magatama could symbolize the shape of the soul * Magatama may be modeled after the shape of the moon * That there is meaning and connotation attached to the shape of the magatama itself (i.e. meaning comes from the form itself, and not that magatama has been patterned after anything else)
==In Japanese mythology== [[File:Amaterasu.png|right|thumb|Artist's rendition of Amaterasu emerging from the cave; Amaterasu holds a magatama necklace in her left hand with a sword]]
The [[Kojiki]] and [[Nihon Shoki]], completed in the 8th century, have numerous references to magatama.<ref name="nipponika"/> They appear in the first chapter of the Nihon Shoki, which largely describes the mythology of Japan. [[Susanoo]], god of the sea and storms, received five hundred magatama from [[Tamanoya no mikoto]], or Ame-no-Futodama-no-mikoto, the jewel-making deity.<ref name="gods">{{Citation | last = Czaja | first = Michael | year = 1974 | title = Gods of myth and stone: phallicism in Japanese folk religion | chapter = The celestial matsuri | edition = 1st | publisher = Weatherhill | place = New York | page = 228 | isbn = 9780834800953 | oclc = 1085538}}</ref> Susanoo went to heaven and presented them to his sister, the sun goddess [[Amaterasu]], who bit off successive parts of the magatama, and blew them away to create other deities.<ref>{{Citation | editor-last = Aston | editor-first = W. G., translator. | year = 1972 | title = Nihongi; chronicles of Japan from the earliest times to A.D. 697 | chapter = Age of the gods | edition = 1st Tuttle | publisher = C.E. Tuttle Co. | place = Rutland, Vt. | pages = 37‚Äì39 | isbn = 9780804809849 | oclc = 354027}}</ref> Tamanoya no mikoto remains the [[kami]] god of magatama, glasses, and cameras. In the legend Amaterasu later shuts herself in a cave. [[Ama-no-Koyane-no-mikoto]] hung magatama, among other objects, on a five hundred-branch [[sakaki]] tree, to successfully lure Amaterasu from the cave.<ref name="gods"/><ref>{{Citation | editor-last = Aston | editor-first = W. G., translator. | year = 1972 | title = Nihongi; chronicles of Japan from the earliest times to A.D. 697 | chapter = Age of the gods | edition = 1st Tuttle | publisher = C.E. Tuttle Co. | place = Rutland, Vt. | page = 40 | isbn = 9780804809849 | oclc = 354027}}</ref> In the year 58, in the reign of the [[Emperor Suinin]], the Nihon shoki records that a dog kills and disembowels a ''mujina'', a type of [[badger]], and a magatama was discovered in its stomach. This magatama was presented to Suinin, who enshrined it at Isonokami Shrine, where it is said to presently reside.<ref>{{Citation | editor-last = Aston | editor-first = W. G., translator. | year = 1972 | title = Nihongi; chronicles of Japan from the earliest times to A.D. 697 | chapter = Suinin | edition = 1st Tuttle | publisher = C.E. Tuttle Co. | place = Rutland, Vt. | pages = 184‚Äì185 | isbn = 9780804809849 | oclc = 354027}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Smyers | first = Karen Ann | year = 1999 | title = The fox and the jewel: shared and private meanings in contemporary Japanese inari worship | chapter = Symbolizing inari: the jewel | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | place = Honolulu | page = 126 | isbn = 9780824820589 | oclc = 39523475}}</ref> A similar practice is described again in the Nihon shoki during the reign of the [[Emperor Ch≈´ai]]. Ch≈´ai made an inspection trip to the Tsukushi, or [[Ky≈´sh≈´]], and was presented with an enormous sakaki tree hung with magatama as well as other sacred objects.<ref>{{Citation | editor-last = Aston | editor-first = W. G., translator. | year = 1972 | title = Nihongi; chronicles of Japan from the earliest times to A.D. 697 | chapter = Chiuai | edition = 1st Tuttle | publisher = C.E. Tuttle Co. | place = Rutland, Vt. | page = 221 | isbn = 9780804809849 | oclc = 354027}}</ref>
===Yasakani no Magatama===
A noted magatama is the {{Nihongo|Yasakani no Magatama|ÂÖ´Â∞∫ÁìäÂãæÁéâ|extra=also {{lang|ja|ÂÖ´Â∞∫ÁìäÊõ≤Áéâ}} and {{lang|ja|ÂÖ´ÂùÇÁìäÊõ≤Áéâ}}}}, one of the three [[Imperial Regalia of Japan]].<ref name="encyclopedia-regalia">{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Encyclopedia of Japan | title = Imperial regalia | url = http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ | accessdate = 2012-04-01 | year = 2012 | publisher = Shogakukan | location = Tokyo}}</ref> Swords, mirrors, and jewels were common objects of status for regional rulers in Japan as early as the Yayoi period,<ref name="yomiuri-1"/> and were further widespread in the Kofun period, as shown by their ubiquitous presence in kofun tumuli.<ref name="yomiuri"/> The Yasakani no Magatama is stored at the {{Nihongo|Kashiko-dokoro|Ë≥¢ÊâÄ|}}, the central shrine of the [[Three Palace Sanctuaries]] at the [[Tokyo Imperial Palace]], and is used in the [[Enthronement of the Japanese Emperor|enthronement ceremony of the Emperor of Japan]].<ref name="encyclopedia-regalia"/>
[[D. C. Holtom|Daniel Clarence Holtom]] stated in 1928 in ''Japanese enthronement ceremonies; with an account of the imperial regalia'' that the Yasakani no Magatama is the only one of the three regalia that exists in its original form;<ref name="holtom-1928">{{Citation | last = Holtom | first = Daniel Clarence | year = 1928 | title = The Japanese enthronement ceremonies; with an account of the imperial regalia | chapter = The jewels | publisher = Kyo Bun Kwan | publication-place = Tokyo | page = 55 | oclc = 1983823}}</ref> post-[[World War II]] scholarship supports the claim. Replicas of the sword and mirror were made as early as the 9th century, and the originals were entrusted to other shrines.<ref name="encyclopedia-imp">{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Encyclopedia of Japan | title = Kurayoshi Plain | url = http://rekishi.jkn21.com/ | accessdate = 2012-04-12 | year = 2012 | publisher = Shogakukan | location = Tokyo}}</ref>
==Usage in Ry≈´ky≈´an religion==
[[D. C. Holtom]] stated that [[noro (priestess)|noro priestesses]] of the [[Ryukyu Kingdom]] wore magatama necklaces early in the twentieth century for ceremonial purposes, but provides no other details.<ref>{{Citation | last = Holtom | first = Daniel Clarence | year = 1928 | title = The Japanese enthronement ceremonies; with an account of the imperial regalia | chapter = The jewels | publisher = Kyo Bun Kwan | publication-place = Tokyo | page = 37 | oclc = 1983823}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Gogok]]: a similarly shaped jewel found in the Korean Peninsula *[[Lingling-o]]: similarly shaped jade, wood, or metal pendants from various ancient Austronesian cultures *[[Pig dragon]] or ''zh≈´l√≥ng'': zoomorphic stone artifacts produced in neolithic China with a similar c- or comma-like shape.

{{overcoverage|date=September 2013}} {{unreferenced|date=February 2010}} [[File:Egerton Drive - geograph.org.uk - 781883.jpg|thumb|right|A medium-density development, in the United Kingdom. Typical features are the apartments in a multi-storey (but not high-rise) building.]]
''' Medium-density housing''' is residential developments that are at higher [[Urban density|densities]] than standard low-density, (or 'broadhectare') suburban subdivisions, but not so high that they might be regarded as [[high density housing]]. In Australia the density of standard suburban residential areas has traditionally been between 8-15 dwellings per [[hectare]]. Medium density housing can range from about 25 to 80 dwellings per hectare, though most commonly the density is between 30 and 40 dwellings/hectare. Such developments may consist of [[Single-family detached home|detached]], [[Semi-detached|semi-attached]] and attached (or [[Multi-family residential|multi-unit]]) housing.
== History == Many traditional types of housing developed prior to car-based cities were at comparable densities, such as the [[Terraced house|terraced]] (row) or [[Courtyard house|courtyard housing]] found in many parts of the world. The inner suburbs in many Australian cities and those [[activity centre]]s developed during the late Victorian suburban boom have examples of medium density housing. Since the 1960s, many Australian states have encouraged [[urban consolidation]] policies which have facilitated the construction of medium density housing.
== Issues == The design of medium density housing requires careful consideration of [[urban design]] principles. In some cases, urban consolidation policies have allowed indiscriminate demolition of existing low-density housing across established residential suburbs, replacing them with various forms of medium density dwellings. Because of this, many medium density developments have been controversial in the last 20‚Äì30 years because of their perceived negative impacts on the [[neighbourhood character]] of established residential areas. Accordingly, there has been an increasing policy emphasis by state and local governments to regulate the design of new medium density developments, such as the [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]n government's [[ResCode]], released in 2001, and the metropolitan strategy, [[Melbourne 2030]], which seeks to confine such housing to [[activity centre]]s.
== See also == * [[List of house types]] * [[Save Our Suburbs]] * [[Transit oriented development]] * [[Urban planning]]
